definition:
Let $A=(a_{ij})$ and $B=(b_{ij})$ be two $n\times n$ matrices. We define
their ** as the matrix whose $(i,j)$th entry is the pair
$(a_{ij},b_{ij})$.

A *Graeco-Latin square* is then the join of two Latin squares.

The name comes from Euler’s use of Greek and Latin letters to
differentiate the entries on each array.

An example of Graeco-Latin square: $$\begin{pmatrix}
a\alpha & b\beta & c\gamma & d\delta\\
d\gamma & c\delta & b\alpha & a\beta\\
b\delta & a\gamma & d\beta &  c\alpha\\
c\beta & d\alpha & a\delta & b\gamma
\end{pmatrix}$$
